bestBHT.bht: To us, Christians, there is one God, the Father, from whom all things derive their existence, and we are directed towards Him as our ultimate purpose. There is one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things were created, and it is by Him that we are restored through the new creation. This strong affirmation of monotheism stands in contrast to the polytheism prevalent in Corinth, and emphasizes the exclusive worship of the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. Christianity discloses the sublime reality underlying the human conviction and emotion that led to the proliferation of false gods.

Henry Alford: TO US... there is ONE GOD, the Father... of Whom are all things."
one Lord Jesus Christ... by Whom are all things, and we by Him."
The inference from the foregoing is that, of itself, the eating of meat offered to idols is a thing indifferent, and therefore allowed.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: is the end for whom and for whose glory believers live.
In :- all things are said to be created (not only 'by'
Also, as all things are by Christ by creation, so they (we
especially) are restored by Him by the new creation.
Albert Barnes: We acknowledge but one God, Whatever the pagan worship, we know that there is but one God; and he alone has a right to rule over us.

The word 'Father' here is not used as applicable to the first person of the Trinity, as distinguished from the second, but is applied to God as God; not as the Father in contradistinction from the Son, but to the divine nature as such, without reference to that distinction.

The work of creation is expressly in this passage ascribed to the Lord Jesus. But the work of creation cannot be performed by a creature. There can be no delegated God, and no delegated omnipotence, or delegated infinite wisdom and omnipresence. The work of creation implies divinity; or it is impossible to prove that there is a God; and if the Lord Jesus made 'all things,' he must be God.
John Calvin: Whatever has its origin from what is foreign to itself, is not eternal, and, consequently, is not God. All things have their origin from one Being: he alone, therefore, is God.
It is by the Son that we are united to him, so he communicates to us through him the reality of existence.
For this reason our Lord is spoken of as one. But in respect of dominion being ascribed to him alone, this is not to be taken as meaning that worldly distinctions are abolished.
Philip Schaff: To us there is one God, the Father, of whom are all things as their primal Source, and we unto him as their last End; and one Lord Jesus Christ, through whom are all things as the immediate Agent in their production, and we through him.

It might have sufficed for the apostle’s purpose to say in opposition to the polytheism that reigned at Corinth ‘To us Christians there is no divinity, and no object of worship, save the one living and true God.’

Now what Christianity does is not to extinguish this conviction and this emotion, out of which the universe came to be thus ignorantly peopled, but to disclose the sublime Reality that underlies all these dreamings.
Archibald T. Robertson: Of whom (εξ ου). As the source (εξ) of the universe (τα παντα as in Romans 11:36; Colossians 1:16) and also our goal is God (εις αυτον) as in Romans 11:36 where δι' αυτου is added whereas here δι' ου (through whom) and δι' αυτου (through him) point to Jesus Christ as the intermediate agent in creation as in Colossians 1:15-20; John 1:3."
Here Paul calls Jesus Lord (Κυριος) and not God (θεος), though he does apply that word to him in Romans 9:5; Titus 2:13; Colossians 2:9; Acts 20:28.

Yet to us there is one God, the Father (αλλ' ημιν εις θεος ο πατηρ). B omits αλλ' here, but the sense calls for it anyhow in this apodosis, a strong antithesis to the protasis ( even if at least, κα ειπερ).
John Gill: In this Christians and Jews agree with the best and wisest philosophers of the Gentiles, that there is but one God

we Christians know him to be 'the Father'; by whom meant either God essentially considered, the one God, Father, Son, and Spirit, called the Father, not in relation to any person in the Godhead, but in relation to the creatures
Christ is the one Lord of all, as he is God over all, the Creator and Former of all things; and he is so likewise as Mediator, having all power, dominion, and government put into his hands
John Wesley: There is but one God — This is exclusive, not of the One Lord, as if he were an inferior deity; but only of the idols to which the One God is opposed.
And one Lord — Equally the object of divine worship.

bhtAttempts.bht: To us, Christians, there is one God, the Father, from whom all things derive their existence, and we are directed towards Him as our ultimate purpose. Furthermore, there is one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things were created and it is by Him that we are restored through the new creation. Although Paul refers to Jesus as Lord and not God in this passage, he does call him God in other places, emphasizing his role as the intermediate agent in creation. This strong affirmation of monotheism and the acknowledgement of the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ as the sole objects of divine worship stands in contrast to the pagan polytheism prevalent in Corinth. Ultimately, Christianity reveals the sublime reality underlying the human conviction and emotion that led to the proliferation of false gods, rather than extinguishing it.

To us, Christians, there is one God, the Father, from whom all things derive their existence, and we are directed towards Him as our ultimate purpose. There is one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things were created, and it is by Him that we are restored through the new creation. This strong affirmation of monotheism stands in contrast to the polytheism prevalent in Corinth, and emphasizes the exclusive worship of the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. Christianity discloses the sublime reality underlying the human conviction and emotion that led to the proliferation of false gods.

To us Christians, there is one God, the Father, the primal Source of all things, and we exist for His glory. Likewise, we recognize one Lord, Jesus Christ, as the immediate Agent in the production of all things and our path to restoration. This strong affirmation of monotheism stands against the polytheism of Corinth. Christianity unveils the profound Reality beneath mankind's imaginative aspirations, instead of extinguishing the conviction and emotion that birthed those myths.

To us Christians, there is one God, the Father, of Whom are all things. And there is one Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom are all things, and we by Him. The eating of meat offered to idols is a thing indifferent, and therefore allowed. The Father is the end for whom believers live, and all things are said to be created for Christ. Christianity discloses the sublime Reality underlying the dreamings and false gods that humans have created, leading us to the recognition of the one true God and Lord.

To us Christians, there is one God, the Father, of Whom are all things. And there is one Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom are all things, and we by Him. The eating of meat offered to idols is a thing indifferent and allowed. Christianity discloses the sublime Reality underlying false gods, revealing the one true God and Lord. This strong affirmation of monotheism contrasts with the polytheism prevalent in Corinth, affirming the exclusive worship of the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
